user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset (size_t size,
                                       int fd,
                                       off_t offset)
{
  if (0 > offset)
    return NULL;
  return MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset64 (size,
                                                  fd,
                                                  (uint64_t) offset);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset:
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset64 (uint64_t size,
                                         int fd,
                                         uint64_t offset)
{
  struct MHD_Response *response;

#if ! defined(HAVE___LSEEKI64) && ! defined(HAVE_LSEEK64)
  if ( (sizeof(uint64_t) > sizeof(off_t)) &&
       ( (size > (uint64_t) INT32_MAX) ||
         (offset > (uint64_t) INT32_MAX) ||
         ((size + offset) >= (uint64_t) INT32_MAX) ) )
    return NULL;
#endif
  if ( ((int64_t) size < 0) ||
       ((int64_t) offset < 0) ||
       ((int64_t) (size + offset) < 0) )
    return NULL;

  response = MHD_create_response_from_callback (size,
                                                MHD_FILE_READ_BLOCK_SIZE,
                                                &file_reader,
                                                NULL,
                                                &free_callback);
  if (NULL == response)
    return NULL;
  response->fd = fd;
  response->is_pipe = false;
  response->fd_off = offset;
  response->crc_cls = response;
  return response;
}
...
#define _MHD_EXTERN __attribute__((visibility("default")))extern
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined both functions and related definitions. None of the functions assign to or otherwise modify their formal parameters. The cast expressions (e.g. (uint64_t) offset, (int64_t) size) only perform type conversions and do not modify the parameter objects. All assignments in the code write to fields of the locally created response object (response->fd, response->fd_off, response->crc_cls), not to any function parameter. The macro expansion of _MHD_EXTERN only affects linkage/visibility and does not change parameter handling. Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided code that appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
